fields.descriptive_line: Portrait miniature of Charles Louis, Count Palatine, watercolour on vellum, painted by Alexander Cooper, ca.1632.
fields.physical_description:
Portrait, head and shoulders, turned slightly to right and looking to front.  Features firmly hatched in brown and sanguine with a little grey shadow, the brown in the eyes noticeably gummy, on a very pale carnation ground; hair in brown wash, hatched with black and with gouache lights; costume washed and hatched with red; the collar in grey wash and the lace modelled in white; background a flat blue wash; traces of a gold marginal strip; on vellum put down on a leaf from a table-book.  
 
<u>Frame:</u> Eighteenth-century copper-gilt locket, the convex back set into and overlapping strip sides with two thread mouldings, and with bezels turned over the back and the glass; the hanger cast in square section and soldered transversely, the sides cut in calyx form with a small ball finial. The locket, especially its hanger, which is archaising for the eighteenth century, may have been intended to complement the sixteenth-century feel of the solid blue background and gold marginal strip.
fields.title: Charles Louis, Count Palatine
fields.materials_techniques: Watercolour on vellum put down on a leaf from a table-book
fields.public_access_description: This miniature is now in very poor condition, which makes it hard to imagine its original vivid colouring. It must have been very striking. Nevertheless, it is one of the most expert examples of Alexander Cooper's work. At this late date, the combination of the solid blue background and the bright rose colour of the costume would have seemed unconventional. It is more reminiscent of 16th-century miniatures than the ones that English miniaturists produced from the mid-1630s. These usually epitomised the sophisticated Baroque manner of Sir Anthony Van Dyck. Unconventional colour combinations and the use of unusual background colours distinguish Alexander Cooper's style.
fields.bibliography: Murdoch, John. Seventeenth-century English Miniatures in the collection of the Victoria and Albert Museum. London: The Stationery Office, 1997. Cat.55. p.106. Full Citation: "55 Charles Louis, Count Palatine (b.1616/17 d.1680) c.1632 P25-1932 Oval 45 x 36mm Features firmly hatched in brown and sanguine with a little grey shadow, the brown in the eyes noticeably gummy, on a very pale carnation ground; hair in brown wash, hatched with black and with gouache lights; costume washed and hatched with red; the collar in grey wash and the lace modelled in white; background a flat blue wash; traces of a gold marginal strip; on vellum put down on a leaf from a table-book. Condition: The face and costume not obviously damaged though probably faded; background scratched and flaked, with some coarse discoloured blue retouches both sides of the head; damp spots. Signed: Lower centre right: AC (see B in Appendix 2). Frame: Eighteenth-century copper-gilt locket, the convex back set into and overlapping strip sides with two thread mouldings, and with bezels turned over the back and the glass; the hanger cast in square section and soldered transversely, the sides cut in calyx form with a small ball finial. The locket, especially its hanger, which is archaising for the eighteenth century, may have been intended to complement the sixteenth-century feel of the solid blue background and gold marginal strip. Provenance: Possibly John Heugh, his sale, Christie's 8 May 1878, lot 94; T Whitcomb Greene, his sale, Sotheby's 7 July 1932, lot 115, bt for the Museum with funds from the Captain H B Murray Bequest. Exhibited: International Fine Arts Exhibition, Rome 1911. Literature: Williamson 1904, vol. T, p. 81, pl. 49, fig. 3; Goulding 1914-15, p. 20; Foster 1914-16, vol. II, p. 160; Accessions 1932, p. 30; A Staring, 'Die Vroege Engelesche Portretminiaturen en ons Land' , Oudheidkundig Jaarboek, XII (March 1944), p. 92 and n. 33, p. 97, fig. 5; Colding 1953, p. 1 18 (exemplifying the use of blue backgrounds); Foskett 1963, p. 72; Schidloff 1964, vol. Ill, pI. 135, fig. 246; Summary Catalogue, 1981, p. 9; Murdoch 1981, p. 121, pl. 15e; Reynolds 1988, p. 62. Despite its condition this miniature has for long been regarded as one of the definitive examples of Alexander Cooper's hand. Its present appearance, which is not impressive as to condition, probably belies its original vividness. The combination of the blue background with the bright rose colour of the costume would have seemed unconventional, reminiscent of the Tudor tradition rather than the sophisticated Flemish Baroque to which the English miniaturists had assimilated by the mid-1630s. It must have been very striking. Unconventional colour combinations and the use of unusual background colours are regarded as distinctive of Alexander Cooper's style. There has been some slight question over the identification. Whitcomb Greene knew the portrait as Charles Louis, but Williamson seems to have questioned this, and he may have been responsible for the suggestion that the sitter was Prince Rupert. Foster failed to mention it in his main listing and included it only in his appendix of sale records. By the time of its appearance at Sotheby's, and notwithstanding Goulding's acceptance of the Charles Louis identification, the portrait was catalogued as Prince Rupert. Long worked on the question, citing a Van Dyck portrait of Charles Louis in the Corcoran Gallery in Washington, and commented tortuously that it 'does not seem to differ sufficiently in features from this miniature to make it certain that the painting and miniature do not represent the same person'. (1) Staring pointed to the original Whitcomb Greene identification and cited the two portraits of Charles Louis in the Buccleuch Collection.(2) Graham Reynolds accepted his view and labelled the miniature accordingly. If of Charles Louis, the date would have to be before 1633, when he was installed as KG. The deep and rounded scallops in the Flemish bobbin-lace of the collar are right for c.1632.(3) This miniature seems thus to be the principal extant version of an image originating from Alexander Cooper himself, which is followed by the unsigned Buccleuch miniature.(4) The other Buccleuch miniature also seems to be an independent type, perhaps a year or two earlier; and A G Reynolds (5) cites a 'comparable portrait ... at Windsor, possibly by N. Thach'.(6) As likenesses they are all compatible with the accepted full-size images of Charles Louis, for example Van Dyck's double portrait with Prince Rupert in the Louvre, a Mierevelt of 1634 at Hardwick Hall, Derbyshire, and another fairly common type, probably a Van Dyck design, of which there was a version in the collection ofCornelia, Countess of Craven (National Gallery). (7) 1 MS note in department files. 2 Kennedy 1917, pls XX and XLI. 3 According to Clare Browne, personal communication, 1993. 4 Kennedy 1917, pI. XLI; Foskett/NPG 1974, no. 161. 5 Personal communication. 6 Cust 1910,case 49/l0. 7 Versions have been sold at Christie's 27-30 May 1932, lot 125, and at Sotheby's 8 June 1966, lot 112."
fields.credit: Purchased with funds from the Murray Bequest
fields.history_note: <u>Provenance:</u> Possibly John Heugh, his sale, Christie's 8 May 1878, lot 94; T Whitcomb Greene, his sale, Sotheby's 7 July 1932, lot 115, bt for the Museum with funds from the Captain H B Murray Bequest.
fields.production_note: It is unclear whether this miniature was painted in England or when the artist was on the Continent in the 1630s.
